## Experiment 1

### Basis spline functions:

$$
\text{bs}(\text{ln}(N); K, p)
$$

Where:

+ $K$ 


### Model 1

Let ( N ), ( M ), and ( P ) be predictors. Then the full model is:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text{ln}(B) =\ & \beta_0 
+ \beta_1 \text{ln}(N) 
+ \beta_2 M 
+ \beta_3 P 
+ \beta_4 \text{ln}(N)  \cdot M 
+ \beta_5 \text{ln}(N)  \cdot P 
+ \beta_6 M \cdot P 
+ \beta_7 \text{ln}(N)  \cdot M \cdot P 
+ \varepsilon
\end{aligned}
$$

where:

$$
\varepsilon \sim \mathcal{N}(0, \sigma^2)
$$

### Model 2

Let ( $f_1(N)$ ) and ( $f_2(N)$ ) be the two basis functions from the linear spline expansion of ( N ) (i.e., ( \texttt{bs(N, df = 2, degree = 1)} )). Then the full model is:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text{ln}(B) =\ & \beta_0 
+ \beta_1 f_1(\text{ln}) 
+ \beta_2 f_2(\text{ln}) 
+ \beta_3 M 
+ \beta_4 P \\
&+ \beta_5 f_1(\text{ln}) \cdot M 
+ \beta_6 f_2(\text{ln}) \cdot M 
+ \beta_7 f_1(\text{ln}) \cdot P 
+ \beta_8 f_2(\text{ln}) \cdot P \\
&+ \beta_9 M \cdot P 
+ \beta_{10} f_1(\text{ln}) \cdot M \cdot P 
+ \beta_{11} f_2(\text{ln}) \cdot M \cdot P 
+ \varepsilon
\end{aligned}
$$

where:

$$
\varepsilon \sim \mathcal{N}(0, \sigma^2)
$$

### Model 3

Let ( f_1(N) ), ( f_2(N) ), and ( f_3(N) ) be the three basis functions from the linear spline expansion of ( N ), i.e., from ( \texttt{bs(N, df = 3, degree = 1)} ). Then the model can be written as:

\[

```{=tex}
\begin{aligned}
log(B) =\ & \beta_0 
+ \beta_1 f_1(N) 
+ \beta_2 f_2(N) 
+ \beta_3 f_3(N) 
+ \beta_4 M 
+ \beta_5 P \\
&+ \beta_6 f_1(N) \cdot M 
+ \beta_7 f_2(N) \cdot M 
+ \beta_8 f_3(N) \cdot M \\
&+ \beta_9 f_1(N) \cdot P 
+ \beta_{10} f_2(N) \cdot P 
+ \beta_{11} f_3(N) \cdot P \\
&+ \beta_{12} M \cdot P \\
&+ \beta_{13} f_1(N) \cdot M \cdot P 
+ \beta_{14} f_2(N) \cdot M \cdot P 
+ \beta_{15} f_3(N) \cdot M \cdot P 
+ \varepsilon
\end{aligned}
```
\]

where ( \varepsilon \sim \mathcal{N}(0, \sigma\^2) ).

### Model 4

Let ( f_1(N) ), ( f_2(N) ), and ( f_3(N) ) be the three basis functions generated from the quadratic spline expansion of ( N ), i.e., from ( \texttt{bs(N, df = 3, degree = 2)} ). Then the model is:

\[

```{=tex}
\begin{aligned}
log(B) =\ & \beta_0 
+ \beta_1 f_1(N) 
+ \beta_2 f_2(N) 
+ \beta_3 f_3(N) 
+ \beta_4 M 
+ \beta_5 P \\
&+ \beta_6 f_1(N) \cdot M 
+ \beta_7 f_2(N) \cdot M 
+ \beta_8 f_3(N) \cdot M \\
&+ \beta_9 f_1(N) \cdot P 
+ \beta_{10} f_2(N) \cdot P 
+ \beta_{11} f_3(N) \cdot P \\
&+ \beta_{12} M \cdot P \\
&+ \beta_{13} f_1(N) \cdot M \cdot P 
+ \beta_{14} f_2(N) \cdot M \cdot P 
+ \beta_{15} f_3(N) \cdot M \cdot P 
+ \varepsilon
\end{aligned}
```
\]

where ( \varepsilon \sim \mathcal{N}(0, \sigma\^2) ).

### Model 5

Let ( f_1(N), f_2(N), f_3(N), f_4(N) ) be the four basis functions from the cubic spline expansion of ( N ), i.e., from ( \texttt{bs(N, df = 4, degree = 3)} ). Then the model is:

\[

```{=tex}
\begin{aligned}
log(B) =\ & \beta_0 
+ \beta_1 f_1(N) 
+ \beta_2 f_2(N) 
+ \beta_3 f_3(N) 
+ \beta_4 f_4(N) 
+ \beta_5 M 
+ \beta_6 P \\
&+ \beta_7 f_1(N) \cdot M 
+ \beta_8 f_2(N) \cdot M 
+ \beta_9 f_3(N) \cdot M 
+ \beta_{10} f_4(N) \cdot M \\
&+ \beta_{11} f_1(N) \cdot P 
+ \beta_{12} f_2(N) \cdot P 
+ \beta_{13} f_3(N) \cdot P 
+ \beta_{14} f_4(N) \cdot P \\
&+ \beta_{15} M \cdot P \\
&+ \beta_{16} f_1(N) \cdot M \cdot P 
+ \beta_{17} f_2(N) \cdot M \cdot P 
+ \beta_{18} f_3(N) \cdot M \cdot P 
+ \beta_{19} f_4(N) \cdot M \cdot P 
+ \varepsilon
\end{aligned}
```
\]

where ( \varepsilon \sim \mathcal{N}(0, \sigma\^2) ).

\begin{aligned}

### Question 3

The Lotka–Volterra competition model for two species is given by:

$$
\frac{dN_{\text{native}}}{dt} = r_{\text{native}} N_{\text{native}} \left( 1 - \frac{N_{\text{native}} + \alpha_{{\text{native, invasive}}} N_{\text{invasive}}}{K_{\text{native}}} \right)
$$

$$
\frac{dN_{\text{invasive}}}{dt} = r_{\text{invasive}} N_{\text{invasive}} \left( 1 - \frac{N_{\text{invasive}} + \alpha_{{\text{invasive, native}}} N_{\text{native}}}{K_{\text{invasive}}} \right)
$$

Where:
- $N_{\text{native}}, N_{\text{invasive}}$: population sizes of the native species and the invasive species
- $r_{\text{native}}, r_{\text{invasive}}$: intrinsic growth rates
- $K_{\text{native}}, K_{\text{invasive}}$: carrying capacities of each species
- $\alpha_{{\text{native, invasive}}}$: competition coefficient measuring effect of the invasive species on the native species
- $\alpha_{{\text{invasive, native}}}$: competition coefficient measuring effect of the native species on the invasive species

#### **1. Coexistence**

Occurs when both species limit themselves more than they limit each other:

$$
\alpha_{\text{invasive,native}} < \frac{K_{\text{native}}}{K_{\text{invasive}}}
\quad \text{and} \quad
\alpha_{\text{native,invasive}} < \frac{K_{\text{invasive}}}{K_{\text{native}}}
$$

Native equilibrium abundance:

$$
N_{\text{native}}^* \;=\; 
\frac{K_{\text{native}} - \alpha_{\text{native,invasive}} \, K_{\text{invasive}}}
     {1 - \alpha_{\text{native,invasive}} \, \alpha_{\text{invasive,native}}}
$$

#### **2. Native wins**

The native species excludes the invasive if:

$$
\frac{K_{\text{native}}}{\alpha_{\text{native,invasive}}} > K_{\text{invasive}}
\quad \text{and} \quad
\frac{K_{\text{invasive}}}{\alpha_{\text{invasive,native}}} < K_{\text{native}}
$$

Native equilibrium abundance:

$$
N_{\text{native}}^* = K_{\text{native}}
$$

---

#### **3. Invasive wins**

The invasive excludes the native if:

$$
\frac{K_{\text{native}}}{\alpha_{\text{native,invasive}}} < K_{\text{invasive}}
\quad \text{and} \quad
\frac{K_{\text{invasive}}}{\alpha_{\text{invasive,native}}} > K_{\text{native}}
$$

Native equilibrium abundance:

$$
N_{\text{native}}^* = N_{\min}
$$

(where $N_{\min}$ is the minimum viable population, often taken as zero)

---

#### **4. Unstable coexistence (priority effects)**

If none of the above conditions hold, outcomes depend on initial conditions:

Resolved stochastically with probability of native victory:

$$
p(\text{native wins}) = \frac{K_{\text{native}}}{K_{\text{native}} + K_{\text{invasive}}}
$$

Assignment:

$$
N_{\text{native}}^* =
\begin{cases}
K_{\text{native}}, & \text{if native “wins”} \\
N_{\min}, & \text{otherwise}
\end{cases}
$$
